title: Plastic or paper? The truth about drinking straws - BBC
body: Paper straws assessed by researchers at the University of Antwerp, Belgium, were found to contain more "forever chemicals" - per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances or PFAS - than plastic. These ...

- BBC News (2023-12-08): The backlash against plastic straws has led to a surge in the popularity of paper, metal, glass, and plant-based alternatives. However, the choice between them may not be as straightforward as it seems. Paper straws, for instance, while not as environmentally harmful as plastic, have been found to contain high levels of "forever chemicals," prompting questions about their true sustainability. The anti-plastic straw movement has raised awareness and spurred action to address plastic pollution on a broader scale, culminating in the negotiation of a Global Plastics Treaty by the UN. Despite the relatively small impact of plastic straws compared to other forms of plastic pollution, they have become a focal point in the campaign for reducing single-use plastics.

- The topic delves into the environmental impact of different straw types, highlighting the drawbacks of paper straws and the larger issue of plastic pollution. It also explores the influence of the anti-plastic straw movement and the broader efforts to address plastic pollution globally.
